[MASK]  customers tend to buy more, are predictable and usually cost less to service than new customers.

After winning a big game,athletes are often asked how they feel.Usually athletes say how  [MASK]  it is to win this big game.On the contrary,the fact is that losing a big game,or in my case,all the games,can be even harder.

From the spectators' point of view,last year's basketball  [MASK]  for my high school team was nothing  short  of an embarrassment.And  while  0--20 is certainly nothing to be proud of,that season had a bigger impact on me than any other.As a team captain,I knew it probably wouldn't be the  easiest  year,but did I ever think we would lose every game?Of course not.Since six of our top players had graduated,it was clear that we were a (n)  young  team who would struggle.The struggle began earlier than expected,  though  ,as our team center was suspended for the season,and two key members decided to  quit  for some reason.At this point,dropping out probably passed through every player's mind,but in the end,we all stuck it out,  swearing  to work still harder.

My mother lived in an old farm house in north Oregon,which was located far from any other neighbors.She lived with her elder brother and sisters.Since there were not enough rooms for them,her two sisters  [MASK]  the bigger bedroom downstairs,her brother in a room down the hall and she slept in the top room of the building.

The first  [MASK]  event that happened in that house was when my mother was about 10 years old.She was staying home sick with her brother.He had gone  downstairs  to the kitchen when my mother heard a voice calling her name from the bottom of the stairs.The voice was  female  but that was impossible since the only other person in the house was her brother.That was followed by footsteps  coming up  the stairs to the top room.A few hours  later  her brother came up to see what she was doing.She asked him who the girl on the stairs was.He said there was no one in the house.

A few weeks later the  [MASK]  event happened.My grandmother was cooking supper in the kitchen.She turned around and two of the chairs were  pulled out  .She pushed them in and went back  cooking  .About ten minutes later she turned around and three of the chairs were pulled out.My grandmother was quite  frightened  by this because only my mother's little sister was home at the time.

The last event at the house was the  [MASK]  and the one that made them move away.Her elder sister Josie was babysitting her younger one,Sarah,when there was a knock on the door.Josie went to  answer  it and no one was there.She went to the  kitchen  for some water and when she returned to the living room,Sarah was  gone  !She ran all over the house and  in the end  found Sarah sleeping in her bed.This was  impossible  because Sarah couldn't  climb  the stairs without help because they were very steep.This frightened her so she woke up Sarah and  took  her downstairs.Then the phone rang.It was my grandma  calling  to say that my grandfather had died and she wouldn't be coming home that night.She was about to turn on the TV  when  she heard a woman's footsteps coming towards her.She turned around but nobody was there.

I was blessed with such a teacher.Here is my praise to a very  [MASK]  teacher, Mr. O'Connor.

I was fortunate to have gone to one of the  [MASK]  public high schools in our region.It won awards for its education.I had many good teachers,but one of them  really  helped me realize the potential that I had inside of myself.His  name  is Mr. O'Connor.He taught English classes.Mr..O'Connor was not a  handsome  guy.I remember he had a very wide face with little hair and  small  but bright eyes.However, he expected the best from his  students  in their studies and morality .He  impressed  me with his personality.His teaching style was attractive.He made me want to be  better  .As a result.I studied hard for better grades.I believe it was his  influence  that helped me succeed in being on the  honor  roll .I enjoyed my high school experience.It was because of Mr..O'Connor that I  realized  that I had huge goals that I wanted to reach.I  ended up  graduating from high school early and I wanted to be a high school English  teacher  just like Mr. O'Connor.As you can see,I continued to study.I  never  gave up on my love for reading and writing,the most amazing gift from Mr. O'Connor.

The question is:Is economic globalization  [MASK]  for all?
According to the World Bank, one of its chief supporters, economic globalization has helped reduce  [MASK]  in a large number of developing countries.

It quotes one study that shows increased wealth  [MASK]  to improved education and longer life in twenty-four developing countries as a result of integration of local economies into the world economy.
Home to some three billion people, these twenty-four countries have seen incomes  [MASK]  at an average rate of five percent--compared to two percent in developed countries.
Those who  [MASK]  globalization claim that economies in developing countries will benefit from new opportunities for small and home-based businesses.
For instance  , small farmers in Brazil who produce nuts that would originally have sold only in  [MASK]  open-air markets can now promote their goods worldwide by the Internet.
Critics take a different view, believing that economic globalization is actually  [MASK]  the gap between the rich and poor.

A study carried out by the U.N.-sponsored World Commission on the Social Dimension of Globalization shows that only a few developing countries have actually  [MASK]  from integration into the world economy and that the poor, the uneducated, unskilled workers, and native peoples have been left behind.
[MASK]  , they maintain that globalization may eventually threaten emerging businesses.

For example, Indian craftsmen who currently seem to benefit from globalization because they are able to  [MASK]  their products may soon face fierce competition that could put them out of  business  .
For example, Indian craftsmen who currently seem to benefit from globalization because they are able to  export  their products may soon face fierce competition that could put them out of  [MASK]  .
The  [MASK]  now is finding a way to create a kind of globalization that works for the benefit of all.

I   [MASK]   to China in September 2014 to work as a teacher in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province, a neighboring city of Shanghai.
I also wanted to   [MASK]   my interest in the environmental sector.

In early September, I met Nick and Nitin, founders of Green Initiatives, at one of their events and, in   [MASK]   of my teaching background, they decided that I would be a good fit for their student outreach program, an environmental education-training program for high school students in Shanghai.

I was given the   [MASK]   of creating their student modules and since then I have put together four higher-level student modules, which introduce key environmental issues 
such as food waste, recycling and sustainable consumption.

AIDS wasn't  [MASK]  we talked about in my country when I was growing up.From then on, I knew that this would be a family  secret  .My parents were not together anymore, and my dad lived alone.For a while, he could take care of himself.But when I was 12, his condition worsened.My father's  other  children lived far away, so it  fell  to me to look after him.We couldn't afford all the necessary medication for him, and  because  Dad was unable to work, I had no money for school supplies and often couldn't  even  buy food for dinner.I would sit  in class  feeling completely  lost  , the teacher's words muffled as I tried to figure out  how  I was going to manage.

I didn't share my burden with anyone.I had seen how people reacted to AIDS.Kids  laughed at  classmates who had parents with the disease.And even adults could be cruel.When my father was moved to the hospital, the nurses would leave his food on the bedside table even though he was  [MASK]  weak to feed himself.I had known that he was going to die,  but  after so many years of keeping his condition a secret, I was completely unprepared when he reached his final days.Sad and  hopeless  , I  called  a woman at the non-profit National AIDS Support.That day, she  kept  me on the phone for hours.I was so lucky to find someone who cared.She saved my life.

Martin Murray is a fifteen-year-old boy.He used to be a "problem child", but a [MASK] conversation with his mother changed his life.He didn't use to give his mother many problems.However, after his father's death a few years ago, Martin's life became much more difficult.His mother had no money to pay for her child's education.To do this, she had to work, and so was often not at home.

His mother looked after him as well as she could.Unfortunately Martin still caused problems for himself and his family.He was not interested in studying and he often got into trouble [MASK] the police.Luckily, his mother was very patient and didn't give up trying to help him.In the end, she made a difficult decision: to send him to a boys' boarding school, Martin hated it and used to cause a lot of trouble.One day, he told his teacher he wanted to leave the school.Even the teacher agreed that Martin was wasting his time.
The head teacher said [MASK] was necessary for Martin to talk with his mother.Martin called his mother, but to his surprise, this phone call changed his life."

It was exactly what I needed," he said., " my mother helped me to understand how much she had given me.She also told me that even though my father was no longer with us, he was watching me and would always be proud of everything good I do.That's when I decided to change.I realize that since my father [MASK] , I have been afraid of being alone, and have tried to make my mother pay more attention to me.
Now Martin has really changed.He has been working hard and is now one of the [MASK] students in his class.How was he able to change?
